text: I M M I G R A N T  W O R K E R S ’  H E A L T H  &  S A F E T Y
label: H1

text: T R A I N  T H E  T R A I N E R    I N T R O D U C T I O N
label: H1

text: This Train-the-Trainer Program was designed to orient community activists and leaders on the
label: BODY

text: basics of workplace health and safety:
label: BODY

text: (1) Identifying hazards at the workplace,
label: BODY

text: (2) Understanding how such hazards can impact workers’ health,
label: BODY

text: (3) Basics on workers’ legal rights to a safe and healthy workplace, and
label: BODY

text: (4) Tools for workers to develop their own solutions in the workplace.
label: BODY

text: The training was developed based in the experiences of the membership of Make the Road
label: BODY

text: New York – for low-wage Latino immigrant workers, many of whom are undocumented.  They
label: BODY

text: work in businesses including restaurants, delis and groceries, small factories, non-union
label: BODY

text: construction, retail, home health care, domestic work, among others.  Many work in very small
label: BODY

text: businesses – often with 10 or fewer employees.  Few enjoy the protections afforded by a union
label: BODY

text: in their job.
label: BODY

text: For many, unsafe working conditions are a routine reality on the job – as is the real risk of
label: BODY

text: retaliation, if workers speak out to the boss.  Likewise, for many supporting families here and in
label: BODY

text: their home country, an unsafe job may seem better than the risk of no job at all.
label: BODY

text: It is in this context that we hope to arm community leaders with a realistic, relevant orientation
label: BODY

text: around health and safety issues.  There is an emphasis in this training on group work and group
label: BODY

text: problem solving – and a goal to identify those steps workers can take together to improve their
label: BODY

text: working conditions, with or without the knowledge or support of the boss.  It is important for
label: BODY

text: workers to understand that the law protects them against retaliation for complaining about
label: BODY

text: unsafe conditions, regardless of immigration status.  However, workers should also understand
label: BODY

text: that if they are fired in retaliation, it may be difficult to win their job back if they lack status.
label: BODY

text: Likewise, workers should also understand that the law affords fairly narrow protections for
label: BODY

text: refusing to perform work that is unsafe.
label: BODY

text: Where unsafe working conditions exist, the goal is to help workers connect to resources such as
label: BODY

text: community organizations like Make the Road – so workers can get the support and back-up to
label: BODY

text: take action, including reporting conditions to government agencies such as OSHA, the federal
label: BODY

text: Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
label: BODY

text: This program is designed for workers with varying levels of formal education and literacy in
label: BODY

text: their native language.  Group participatory activities, pictures, and other formats ensure that all
label: BODY

text: workers can actively and equally participate in the exercises.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: Finally, this training covers the most fundamental rights of workers under the federal OSH Act,
label: BODY

text: and is intended for workers who work primarily in what OSHA classifies as “miscellaneous.”
label: BODY

text: OSHA issues very detailed regulations for many specific jobs, and many specific hazards, that
label: BODY

text: are beyond the scope of this training.  For more detailed information to supplement these
label: BODY

text: exercises, trainers are encouraged to read the Introduction to OSHA Instructor Guide
label: BODY

text: published by OSHA on its website.1  The OSHA website has many useful resources for workers
label: BODY

text: as well.2
label: BODY

text: About Make the Road New York:
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York is a community-based nonprofit organization with centers in
label: BODY

text: Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, and Suffolk County Long Island, New York.  Make the Road
label: BODY

text: New York builds the power of Latino and working class communities to achieve dignity and
label: BODY

text: justice through organizing, policy innovation, transformative education, and survival services.
label: BODY

text: The organization’s nearly 9,000 members – primarily low-income Latino immigrants – tackle the
label: BODY

text: key issues facing their communities, including workplace justice, tenants’ rights, civil rights,
label: BODY

text: public education, health care access, adult literacy, and workforce development.  For more than
label: BODY

text: 14 years, Make the Road has focused in particular on helping low-wage immigrant workers
label: BODY

text: enforce their most basic rights on the job – from receiving the minimum wage and overtime to
label: BODY

text: ensuring a healthy and safe work environment.  This training is designed to help organizations
label: BODY

text: across the country work with community leaders and activists, to learn about workers’ rights to
label: BODY

text: a safe work environment and strategies to protecting their own safety and health.
label: BODY

text: Acknowledgments:
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New drew from many wonderful resources to create this training.  In particular,
label: BODY

text: the exercises with graphics included below are modified from similar exercises included in the
label: BODY

text: English as a Second Language curriculum created by the New York Committee on Occupational
label: BODY

text: Safety & Health (NYCOSH) entitled Taking Action for a Safe Workplace: Materials for English
label: BODY

text: Language Learner Teachers (2005).  Many thanks as well to the people who contributed their
label: BODY

text: ideas, time, and energy to this project, including in particular Luzdary Giraldo, Angela
label: BODY

text: Villanueva, Nycole Garcia, Hilary Klein, and Amy Carroll.
label: BODY

text: 1 See www.osha.gov/dte/outreach/intro_osha/intro_to_osha_guide.pdf.  For other useful handouts and
label: BODY

text: information, see also www.osha.gov/dte/outreach/teachingaids.html.  Also visit the website of the Centers for
label: BODY

text: Disease Control for more information.  http://www.cdc.gov/Workplace/.
label: BODY

text: 2 http://www.osha.gov/workers.html

text: T R A I N E R  T I P S  &  P R E P A R A T I O N
label: H1

text: Before you hold the training, think through the following in preparation:
label: BODY

text:  Work Space
label: BODY

text: Know the space in which you will hold the training.  It is best to have the group
label: BODY

text: sit in a circle for large group activities.  For small group work, make sure there is
label: BODY

text: sufficient space for people to spread out.
label: BODY

text:  Managing Questions:
label: BODY

text: Post a large sheet of butcher paper at the start of the day, labeled “Questions”
label: BODY

text: or “Preguntas” (in Spanish).  Encourage participants to ask questions as you
label: BODY

text: proceed.  If a question is not related to the immediate topic, or if you do not
label: BODY

text: know the answer yourself, have them write the question up on the sheet (or
label: BODY

text: write it for them, if they do not feel comfortable writing).  At the end of the
label: BODY

text: training, run through the list and see how many questions are not yet answered.
label: BODY

text: Prepare to return with an answer yourself, or assign research to participants.
label: BODY

text:  Group Dynamic
label: BODY

text: Establish a practice to encourage “Step Up/Step Back.”  Participants who speak
label: BODY

text: often should be encouraged to “step back” so others may contribute.
label: BODY

text: Participants who are shy about offering ideas should be encouraged to “step
label: BODY

text: up.”  In group discussions, wait to call on someone a second time until all others
label: BODY

text: have had a chance to speak.  Also consider gender balance – ensure that all
label: BODY

text: participate equally in group discussions.
label: BODY

text:  Ground Rules
label: BODY

text: Have the group establish ground rules that you write up at the front of the room.
label: BODY

text: Good rules include shutting off cell phones, respect for everyone’s ideas, “one
label: BODY

text: voice” (only one person speaks at a time), and maintaining the confidentiality of
label: BODY

text: what is shared in the group.
label: BODY

text:  Visuals
label: BODY

text: It is very useful to post visuals and information around the meeting space.  You
label: BODY

text: can post “teasers” – such single-word signs including “OSHA,” “HAZARD,” and
label: BODY

text: “SAFE,” as well as signs with statistics you will review (injury rates, etc.).
label: BODY

text: A G E N D A  &  P L A N  F O R  T R A I N I N G
label: H1

text: The following agenda is intended to take approximately 10 hours to complete.  It can be
label: BODY

text: shortened, and completed in a single day, or broken into two portions spread over two days.
label: BODY

text: D A Y  O N E  –  A P P R O X .  5  H O U R S
label: BODY

text: I N T R O D U C T I O N S  &  O V E R V I E W
label: BODY

text: 3 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: Introduce yourself & role with the organization
label: BODY

text: Introduce the host organization, e.g.:
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York builds the power of Latino and working class communities
label: BODY

text: to achieve dignity and justice through organizing, policy innovation, transformative
label: BODY

text: education, and survival services.  With nearly 9,000 members at our four
label: BODY

text: community-based centers, we organize around workers’ rights issues – including
label: BODY

text: helping workers fight to for workplaces that are safe and healthy.
label: BODY

text: Go around the circle asking participants to introduce themselves by sharing:
label: BODY

text: Their name
label: BODY

text: ii.
label: BODY

text: Their current job (or a recent job, if not working)
label: BODY

text: iii.
label: BODY

text: A movement that typifies what they do at work.  (You can kick of the round
label: BODY

text: by demonstrating: for instance, “I am a teacher” – and mime some aspect of
label: BODY

text: teaching.)
label: BODY

text:  Keep track of names and jobs/industries.  You may divide groups according to
label: BODY

text: jobs later in the day, if participants divide neatly into separate industries.
label: BODY

text: Review the brief agenda & goals for the day
label: BODY

text: Goal: For this group of community leaders and activists to learn about workplace
label: BODY

text: hazards; workers’ legal rights to a safe workplace; and tactics and strategies workers
label: BODY

text: can use to minimize risks in the workplace.  As leaders, participants will have the
label: BODY

text: duty to share what they have learned with family, friends, and co-workers.
label: BODY

text: Ask participants to add any other goals to this basic mission statement.
label: BODY

text: Ask participants to set “Ground Rules” for the day – using the basics outlined above
label: BODY

text: as a starting point.
label: BODY

text: I N T R O D U C T I O N  T O  W O R K E R S  H E A L T H  &  S A F E T Y  I S S U E S
label: BODY

text: 1 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: This activity is designed for the group to get a sense of how common unsafe working
label: BODY

text: conditions are in the community.  You will read a series of questions and ask those answering
label: BODY

text: “yes” to physically signal their response without speaking.
label: BODY

text:  Step In/Step Out format.  Ask everyone to stand in a large circle.  Those
label: BODY

text: answering “yes” to the question should take one step into the circle, while those
label: BODY

text: answering “no” remain where they are.
label: BODY

text:  Stand Up/Sit Down format.  If you do not have a lot of room, ask participants
label: BODY

text: to simply stand up if their answer is “yes,” or to remain seated if “no.”
label: BODY

text: Questions (create more question as are relevant to your participants)
label: BODY

text: 1) I have had to do work that I thought was unsafe at least once in a job.
label: BODY

text: 2) I have seen others do work that I thought was unsafe.
label: BODY

text: 3) I have been hurt on the job.
label: BODY

text: 4) I have seen someone else get hurt on the job.
label: BODY

text: 5) I have been hurt on the job so badly I had to go to the doctor.
label: BODY

text: 6) I know someone who has been hurt so badly on the job they had to go to the doctor.
label: BODY

text: Reflection:
label: BODY

text: How do participants feel having done the exercise?  What do they think about it?
label: BODY

text: U N K N O W N  F A C T O R Y  S T O R Y
label: BODY

text: 3 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: This activity is intended to set the historical stage for worker safety and health issues,
label: BODY

text: and to familiarize participants with phrases such as “workplace safety,” “hazard,” and
label: BODY

text: “occupational safety.”  The handout [Handout #1: Factory Story] is the story of the historic
label: BODY

text: Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire, which occurred in 1911 near Washington Square Park in
label: BODY

text: Manhattan.3
label: BODY

text: Note: the participant handout does not include the date, the name of the factory, the location,
label: BODY

text: or any details about the workers.  Have participants read the story aloud – and answer the
label: BODY

text: discussion questions included on the handout and below.  This exercise is intended to show
label: BODY

text: workers how worker safety and health risks continue – despite tragedies like this fire.
label: BODY

text: Pass out Handout #1 to the group.  If all participants are comfortable reading aloud, have each
label: BODY

text: participant read 1-2 sentences, going around in a circle until the entire story is completed.  If
label: BODY

text: some participants are unable to read, ask for volunteers to read the story aloud.
label: BODY

text: 3 For more detailed information about this event, see http://www.ilr.cornell.edu/trianglefire/.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: Discussion Questions (also included on bottom of handout)
label: BODY

text: 1) Where in New York City do you think this took place?  What borough or
label: BODY

text: neighborhood?
label: BODY

text: 2) What kind of factory do you think it was?
label: BODY

text: 3) What year do you think it happened?
label: BODY

text: 4) How many days a week and hours a day do you think these workers worked?
label: BODY

text: 5) Who do you think these workers were?  Where were they from?  Were the men
label: BODY

text: or women?  How old do you think they were?
label: BODY

text: 6) What are some of the reasons this disaster happened?
label: BODY

text: As you facilitate a discussion, fill in the actual facts of the tragedy:
label: BODY

text: • The fire took place in New York City on March 25, 1911.
label: BODY

text: • The factory was located at 23-29 Washington Place, between Greene Street and
label: BODY

text: Washington Square East in Manhattan, New York City (Greenwich Village).
label: BODY

text: • The Triangle Waist Company was one of the largest blouse makers in New York
label: BODY

text: City, specializing in “shirtwaists,” the very popular women's blouse of the era.
label: BODY

text: • 146 people died as a result of the fire: 129 women and 17 men.
label: BODY

text: • Many of the workers were young women, most of them Italian and European
label: BODY

text: Jewish immigrants between 16 and 23 years old.  Some were as young as 14.
label: BODY

text: • They worked nine hours a day on weekdays, plus seven hours on Saturdays
label: BODY

text: (notably less than many garment factory workers today).
label: BODY

text: Current Day Snap Shot [Handout #2]
label: BODY

text: End by reviewing statistics about injury rates today, for example:4
label: BODY

text:  In 2009, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported an average of 12 workers
label: BODY

text: were killed every day on the job in the U.S.  (Total 4,340 workers a year.)
label: BODY

text:  That same year, another 50,000 were killed from occupational disease – diseases
label: BODY

text: caused by conditions at work.
label: BODY

text:  Estimates suggest that about 8 million to 12 million job injuries or illnesses occur
label: BODY

text: every year.
label: BODY

text:  Latino workers continued to have a greater risk of job fatalities. There were 668
label: BODY

text: fatalities among Latino workers.  Of those, 59% (393) were born outside the U.S.
label: BODY

text:  The first federal law to protect workers’ health and safety on the job was not passed
label: BODY

text: until 1970 – nearly 60 years after the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire.
label: BODY

text: Discussion: Spend a few minutes asking workers to comment on why so many workers are still
label: BODY

text: hurt on the job and why the rates of fatalities are higher for Latino workers.
label: BODY

text: 4 Statistics taken from the AFL-CIO Report Death on the Job: The Toll of Neglect, April 2001.  Available at
label: BODY

text: http://www.aflcio.org/issues/safety/memorial/doj_2011.cfm.
label: BODY

text: * *  1 0  M I N U T E  B R E A K  * *
label: BODY

text: H A Z A R D  M A P P I N G  A T  T H E  A B C  G A R M E N T  F A C T O R Y
label: BODY

text: 6 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: for participants to start identifying safety hazards caused by physical risks – slippery
label: BODY

text: floors, broken machinery, etc.  These are often the most obvious hazards, and the first that
label: BODY

text: participants identify.
label: BODY

text: GROUP BRAINSTORM: Ask for volunteers to give examples of a “hazard” on the job that might
label: BODY

text: cause harm to a worker’s safety or health.  They can use examples from their own jobs, or using
label: BODY

text: their imagination.
label: BODY

text: If participants give an example of an injury, e.g., a burn, ask them to give the cause of the injury,
label: BODY

text: e.g., hot oil or an open flame.  Explain that the cause of the injury is the workplace hazard.
label: BODY

text: As the list of examples grows, point out that hazards fall in to different categories:
label: BODY

text: 1. Safety hazards: these are physical conditions that can cause harm, such as slippery
label: BODY

text: floors, broken ladders, or high heat.
label: BODY

text: 2. Chemicals exposure: hazardous chemicals (cleaning products, chemicals used in
label: BODY

text: production, etc.) are common in many jobs.
label: BODY

text: 3. Biological hazards: workers may get exposed to viruses or bacteria, blood, insects, or
label: BODY

text: other biological hazards on the job.
label: BODY

text: 4. Misc. hazards: this can include things like workplace violence.
label: BODY

text: Next, divide group up again into small groups of maximum 4 participants per group.  You can
label: BODY

text: either keep groups the same as earlier, or mix participants up.  Tell participants they all work
label: BODY

text: together at the ABC Garment Factory and that they are meeting after work one day to talk
label: BODY

text: about some of the health and safety problems they are having on the job.
label: BODY

text: Distribute:
label: BODY

text: Handout #3 – drawing of the ABC Garment Factory (one per participant)
label: BODY

text: Handout #4 – the health & safety checklist
label: BODY

text: Review the example provided in the checklist to explain how to use the chart.  If people still
label: BODY

text: seem uncertain, ask them to share another example of a hazard with the group, and the effect
label: BODY

text: or injury it might cause.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: From Handout #4:
label: BODY

text: HAZARD & LOCATION
label: BODY

text: EFFECT OR INJURY
label: BODY

text: Example:
label: BODY

text: Meat slicer / sharp blade
label: BODY

text: Cuts
label: BODY

text: Ask the groups to spend 20 minutes looking at the drawing, and imagining that they work in
label: BODY

text: that environment.  What kind of safety risks are there?  What might threaten their health?  Ask
label: BODY

text: them to write down every possible HAZARD or UNSAFE CONDITION that they think exists in the
label: BODY

text: factory.
label: BODY

text: Emphasize that they should use their:
label: BODY

text:  EYES: imagine looking around at the factory
label: BODY

text:  EARS: imagine listening to the typical sounds
label: BODY

text:  NOSE: imagine what smells might be present
label: BODY

text: Each group should choose a name for their group and a Secretary to take notes.  After about
label: BODY

text: 15-20 minutes, reconvene as a large group.  Taking turns, have each group read out one of the
label: BODY

text: hazards they identified.  On butcher paper at the front, write up the answers.  Keep going
label: BODY

text: around until all groups have shared all their hazards.
label: BODY

text: Explain that you will return to this exercise in a little while.
label: BODY

text: B R E A K  –  1 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: H A Z A R D  M A P P I N G  C O N T ’ D .  –  “ I N V I S I B L E ”  H A Z A R D S
label: BODY

text: 2 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: to help participants identify not only safety hazards that are obvious to the eye, but
label: BODY

text: other more “invisible” hazards.  These hazards are sometimes identifiable more from the
label: BODY

text: symptom than the hazard – you feel dizzy, your eyes water, your nose runs or itches, you get a
label: BODY

text: headache, etc.
label: BODY

text: Transition from the factory exercise by explaining that workers are often exposed to “invisible”
label: BODY

text: hazards – for example, chemical or biological exposure.
label: BODY

text: Distribute Handout #5, Maria’s Nail Salon.  Ask everyone to imagine that they work in this nail
label: BODY

text: salon, six days a week, 10 hours a day.  Have them study the drawing, taking note of possible
label: BODY

text: hazards in the picture.
label: BODY

text: Teaching trick    You can also bring a bottle of hairspray to class and spray a bit and/or
label: BODY

text: a bottle of nail polish and nail polish remover that you simply open and leave sitting out
label: BODY

text: for a few minutes.
label: BODY

text: Activity: explain that participants will each have the opportunity to act out, without using
label: BODY

text: words, how they think they would feel after working in the nail salon for a few weeks.  Ask for
label: BODY

text: 4-5 volunteers to come to the front of the room to act out how they feel.  Have the rest of the
label: BODY

text: group guess what the symptoms are.  Some examples could be: holding your head because it
label: BODY

text: hurts; rubbing your eyes; blowing your nose: acting dizzy, etc.  You can act out one to get the
label: BODY

text: group started.
label: BODY

text: Questions:
label: BODY

text: (1) What might be causing these symptoms?
label: BODY

text: (2) How is this caused?  (Skin contact, breathe in chemicals or fumes, drink it)
label: BODY

text: 3 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: to help participants further identify how hazards impact their body and their health, as
label: BODY

text: they started to do with the nail salon exercise.   Participants will identify both short-term
label: BODY

text: problems – cuts, burns, accidents – as well as longer-term health impacts of hazards.
label: BODY

text: Provide each participant with a large piece of butcher paper, markers, and dot stickers in
label: BODY

text: different colors.  Ask them to draw the outline of their own body and label their page at the top
label: BODY

text: with (1) their name and (2) their job.  Ask them to take 10 minutes to put stickers on their body
label: BODY

text: map indicating where they have pain, stress, or injuries from their job.  Encourage them to note
label: BODY

text: both immediate pains – from cuts or burns – as well as longer-term pains – muscle aches,
label: BODY

text: breathing problems, etc.
label: BODY

text: If you prefer, you can ask participants to complete Handout #6 for the body mapping.
label: BODY

text: Report-back: depending on the group, you can have workers report-back in small groups
label: BODY

text: divided by type of job or industry.  If the large group is very diverse, in terms of types of jobs,
label: BODY

text: create mixed groups and ask workers to spend 2 minutes per person explaining their body map
label: BODY

text: to the group.
label: BODY

text: Large group discussion: Ask participants to share any reactions to what they learned from the
label: BODY

text: activity.  Did they see any patterns?  What kinds of health impacts did participants notice most
label: BODY

text: frequently?  In leading the discussion, help the group identify and discuss longer-term health
label: BODY

text: consequences of workplace hazards, such as long-term respiratory problems, ergonomic issues,
label: BODY

text: etc.
label: BODY

text: * *  1 0  M I N U T E  B R E A K  * *
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 6 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: Now that participants have identified hazards, and explored how hazards impact their
label: BODY

text: health, these activities will help participants think about steps they can take to deal with
label: BODY

text: hazards in the workplace.
label: BODY

text: Explain to participants that now that they have started identifying the hazards at the ABC
label: BODY

text: Garment Factory and at Maria’s Nail Salon, they are going to brainstorm ways to lessen or get
label: BODY

text: rid of these hazards.  Explain that their goals, in order of importance should be to:
label: BODY

text: REMOVE, CONTROL & PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT.
label: BODY

text: This means:
label: BODY

text: 1) Removing the hazard.  The best option is to completely get rid of the hazard
label: BODY

text: altogether.  For example, you could substitute non-toxic materials or replace broken
label: BODY

text: equipment.  But….
label: BODY

text: 2) Controlling the hazard.  It is not always possible to completely remove a hazard.  In
label: BODY

text: that case, your next question should be: how can you control it?  How can you
label: BODY

text: minimize it?  Consider both administrative and engineering controls.
label: BODY

text: a. There might be physical changes – mats for slippery floors; guards on machines,
label: BODY

text: that help lessen the danger.
label: BODY

text: b. There might be way to train workers to work more safely, etc.
label: BODY

text: 3) Protecting against the hazard.  The last line of defense is to protect against the
label: BODY

text: hazard by providing workers with personal protective equipment (“PPE”) – like
label: BODY

text: gloves, masks, etc.
label: BODY

text: Write (1) REMOVE, (2) CONTROL, (3) PPE on butcher paper at the front of the room.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: For 20 minutes in their small groups, have the participants revisit either the ABC Factory or
label: BODY

text: Maria’s Nail Salon (their choice), and brainstorm solutions using this chart from Handout #7:
label: BODY

text: Hazard
label: BODY

text: Solution
label: BODY

text: Example:
label: BODY

text: Meat slicer / sharp blade
label: BODY

text: Guards on machine; training workers to use; lock-out to
label: BODY

text: shut off machine if there is jam, etc.
label: BODY

text: As they brainstorm, they should:
label: BODY

text: (1) Include solutions that are specific and relevant to the situation;
label: BODY

text: (2) Indicate whether the solutions involve removing, controlling, or protecting against
label: BODY

text: the hazard; and
label: BODY

text: (3) Note which solutions workers can take on their own, and  which solutions require
label: BODY

text: the employer to take action.
label: BODY

text: (4) Flag the 3-4 best solutions to a hazard that they are proposing.
label: BODY

text: Report back: each group should spend 5 minutes reporting back on the 3-4 best solutions they
label: BODY

text: brainstormed as a group.
label: BODY

text: GROUP DISCUSSION: Ask for commentaries from the group based on the activity.  Ask them in
label: BODY

text: particular to talk about what solutions workers can implement on their own, and what solutions
label: BODY

text: require the employer’s involvement.  As the facilitator, you should help manage the
label: BODY

text: conversation – challenge the group when solutions are not realistic, raise other ideas that occur
label: BODY

text: to you but that do not come out in the group discussion, etc.
label: BODY

text: D A Y  T W O  –  A P P R O X .  4 . 5  H O U R S
label: BODY

text: R E - A S S E M B L E  F O R  D A Y  2
label: BODY

text: 1 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: Welcome participants back to day two of the training.  To start, have participants sit in a circle
label: BODY

text: in a large group and going around, say their name and one thing that they learned or that
label: BODY

text: impacted them from the first day’s activities.
label: BODY

text: W O R K E R S ’  L E G A L  R I G H T S
label: BODY

text: 4 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: To orient the group to their basic legal rights under federal and state law to work in a
label: BODY

text: safe and healthy workplace.
label: BODY

text: Remind participants about the activities they did at the end of the prior day: they identified
label: BODY

text: hazards, and proposed solutions.  Remind participants that some of the most important
label: BODY

text: solutions they proposed require the employer to take steps.
label: BODY

text: Poll participants: what do you think the boss would do if you made these suggestions at work?
label: BODY

text: Explain that you will now review workers’ basic legal rights.
label: BODY

text: Ask the group to share:
label: BODY

text: 1) the name of the federal law that protects workers’ safety and health on the job
label: BODY

text: 2) the name of the federal agency that enforces this law
label: BODY

text:  Write up on the board or on paper “OSHA” – explain that OSHA, which is part of the
label: BODY

text: Department of Labor, enforces the federal Occupational Safety and Health Act, the main
label: BODY

text: law that protects workers on the job.
label: BODY

text:  Ask the group to guess what year the law was passed: answer is 1970.
label: BODY

text: Explain that the OSH Act applies to:
label: BODY

text: 1) Basically all workers and
label: BODY

text: 2) It applies to workers regardless of their immigration status.5
label: BODY

text: OSHA works to:
label: BODY

text: 1) develop rules about workplace safety;
label: BODY

text: 2) enforce those rules through inspecting workplaces;
label: BODY

text: 3) track workplace accidents; and
label: BODY

text: 5 Workers typically not covered by OSHA include the self-employed; immediate family members of farm employers
label: BODY

text: who do not employ any outside employees; and workers covered under another federal law (such as mineworkers
label: BODY

text: or those in the Coast Guard).
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: 4) train workers and employees on workplace health and safety.
label: BODY

text: Explain that you have 5 basic rights under OSHA.  Ask group to brainstorm what these rights
label: BODY

text: might be – write ideas up on the board.  Then review the 5 key rights:
label: BODY

text: 1) A healthy and safe workplace;
label: BODY

text: 2) Information;
label: BODY

text: 3) Training;
label: BODY

text: 4) To request that an unsafe workplace situation be changed (and to file a complaint with
label: BODY

text: OSHA about it); and
label: BODY

text: 5) Protection from retaliation for reporting unsafe working conditions.
label: BODY

text:  Distribute Handout #8, workers rights under OSHA.
label: BODY

text: Go back one by one to discuss them in more depth.
label: BODY

text: 1) Healthy and safe workplace:
label: BODY

text: a. You have the legal right to work free from known hazards that can cause death
label: BODY

text: or serious physical harm to you.  This includes having tools and equipment that is
label: BODY

text: in good condition an regularly maintained.
label: BODY

text: b. Where an unsafe condition exists, an employer must first attempt to reduce a
label: BODY

text: hazard to a safe level by using engineering or administrative control, for example
label: BODY

text: by substituting less hazardous materials or work practices.
label: BODY

text: c. If engineering and administrative controls cannot adequately reduce the hazard
label: BODY

text: of the working condition, then an employer must provide a worker personal
label: BODY

text: protective equipment (PPE) at no cost to the worker.
label: BODY

text: 2) Information:
label: BODY

text: a. Your rights as a worker – the OSHA poster.  Distribute copies of the poster and
label: BODY

text: ask if participants have seen it posted at their job.
label: BODY

text: b. Information on dangerous chemicals used in your job.
label: BODY

text: i. Explain that employers must have Material Safety Data Sheets for all
label: BODY

text: hazardous chemicals used.  Distribute the sample MSDS for review.
label: BODY

text: ii. Employers are to provide training on hazardous chemicals that can be
label: BODY

text: understood by the worker (including in the worker’s primary language).
label: BODY

text: c. Information on injuries or illnesses that happen at your worksite.
label: BODY

text: i. If there are more than 10 workers on the job, the employer must keep an
label: BODY

text: OSHA 300 log of all injuries and illnesses.
label: BODY

text: d. Copies of your own medical records, if kept by the employer.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: 3) Training: your employer must train you to perform your job safely, according to the
label: BODY

text: OSHA rules that apply.
label: BODY

text: 4) Reporting unsafe working conditions.  You can:
label: BODY

text: a. Ask your employer to correct unsafe working conditions;
label: BODY

text: b. File a complaint with OSHA anonymously about the condition;
label: BODY

text: c. Participate in the OSHA investigation and get information about the resolution.
label: BODY

text: d. Workers should call OSHA immediately (1-800-321-OSHA) to report imminent
label: BODY

text: dangers.  To count as an “imminent” danger, there must be:
label: BODY

text: i. A threat of death or serious physical harm (meaning such severe harm to
label: BODY

text: a part of your body you will lose use or not be able to use it well).
label: BODY

text: ii. Exposure to a health hazard (e.g., a chemical) that will shorten the
label: BODY

text: worker’s life or substantially reduce the worker’s physical or mental
label: BODY

text: abilities (harm does not have to happen immediately).
label: BODY

text: 5) Protection against retaliation:6
label: BODY

text: a. Your employer can’t retaliate against you for reporting an unsafe condition or
label: BODY

text: participating in an OSHA investigation.  Report instances of retaliation to OSHA
label: BODY

text: immediately, but no later than 30 days after it happens!
label: BODY

text: QUESTION: When can a worker refuse to do unsafe work and be protected against retaliation?
label: BODY

text:  OSHA does not necessarily protect a worker who refuses to do work as ordered by
label: BODY

text: the employer, even if that work may be unsafe.  Refusing work can result in discipline
label: BODY

text: by the employer.
label: BODY

text:  However, if a worker reasonably believes, in good faith, that they are being exposed
label: BODY

text: to an imminent danger, the worker may refuse to perform the work as ordered.
label: BODY

text: o "Good faith" means that even if an imminent danger is not found to exist,
label: BODY

text: the worker had reasonable grounds to believe that it did exist.
label: BODY

text: o As noted above, “imminent dangers” are serious, immediate dangers that
label: BODY

text: are likely to cause serious injury.
label: BODY

text:  While you may have a right to refuse to engage in work that presents an imminent
label: BODY

text: danger, you do not have the right to walk off the job.
label: BODY

text: 6 The information on retaliation is drawn nearly verbatim from OSHA’s guide, found at:
label: BODY

text: www.osha.gov/dte/outreach/intro_osha/intro_to_osha_guide.pdf.
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: When might you decide to refuse to do work that presents an imminent danger?  Your right
label: BODY

text: to refuse to do a task is protected if all of the following conditions are met:
label: BODY

text: (1) Where possible, you have asked the employer to eliminate the danger, and the
label: BODY

text: employer failed to do so; and
label: BODY

text: (2) You refused to work in "good faith." This means that you must genuinely believe
label: BODY

text: that an imminent danger exists. Your refusal cannot be a disguised attempt to harass
label: BODY

text: your employer or disrupt business; and
label: BODY

text: (3) A reasonable person would agree that there is a real danger of death or serious
label: BODY

text: injury; and
label: BODY

text: (4) There isn't enough time, due to the urgency of the hazard, to get it corrected
label: BODY

text: through regular enforcement channels, such as requesting an OSHA inspection.
label: BODY

text: When all of these conditions are met, you should take the following steps:
label: BODY

text: (1) Ask your employer to correct the hazard;
label: BODY

text: (2) Ask your employer for other work;
label: BODY

text: (3) Tell your employer that you won't perform the work unless and until the hazard is
label: BODY

text: corrected; and
label: BODY

text: (4) Remain at the worksite until ordered to leave by your employer.
label: BODY

text:  If your employer discriminates against you for refusing to perform the dangerous
label: BODY

text: work, contact OSHA immediately.
label: BODY

text: When you file your complaint, you must demonstrate that:
label: BODY

text: 1) You were engaged in activity protected under the Act, such as notifying your
label: BODY

text: employer of an unsafe working condition;
label: BODY

text: 2) Your employer knew about your protected activity; and
label: BODY

text: 3) It was because of your protected activity that the employer took adverse action
label: BODY

text: against you.
label: BODY

text: Adverse action is generally defined as any action that would dissuade a reasonable employee
label: BODY

text: from engaging in protected activity. Depending upon the circumstances of the case, "adverse"
label: BODY

text: action can include:
label: BODY

text: • Firing or laying off
label: BODY

text: • Blacklisting
label: BODY

text: • Demoting
label: BODY

text: • Denying overtime or promotion
label: BODY

text: Make the Road New York  Immigrant Workers’ Health & Safety  Train the Trainer Curriculum
label: BODY

text: This material was produced under grant SH20830SH0 from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration,
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Labor.  It does not necessarily reflect the views or policies of the U.S. Department of Labor, nor
label: BODY

text: does mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
label: BODY

text: • Disciplining
label: BODY

text: • Denial of benefits
label: BODY

text: • Failure to hire or rehire
label: BODY

text: • Intimidation
label: BODY

text: • Making threats
label: BODY

text: • Reassignment affecting prospects
label: BODY

text: for promotion
label: BODY

text: • Reducing pay or hours
label: BODY

text: Closing Discussion: Ask for questions or commentaries from the group.
label: BODY

text: B R E A K  –  1 0  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: F I N A L  S K I T
label: BODY

text: 7 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: for participants to synthesize the information they have learned in an interactive activity
label: BODY

text: that can be used to train other groups of workers.
label: BODY

text: Explain that each small group will have 25 minutes to prepare a skit that incorporates what they
label: BODY

text: have learned from the training.  Participants are free to choose the focus on their skit: they can
label: BODY

text: revisit earlier activities/examples and use those for the substance of the skit; they can “invent”
label: BODY

text: a workplace; or they can use an example from their own lives.  Emphasize that the groups will
label: BODY

text: have limited time to develop their full skit, so they should focus on building the skit rather than
label: BODY

text: spending time choosing a topic.
label: BODY

text: The skits should be 8-10 minutes long.  Each skit should:
label: BODY

text: 1) Illustrate a group of workers dealing with some kind of hazard at their job;
label: BODY

text: 2) Make clear what the hazard is that is a problem;
label: BODY

text: 3) Show what harm that hazard is causing;
label: BODY

text: 4) Illustrate tactics the workers can use to lessen the risk of the hazard.
label: BODY

text: Give the groups 25 minutes to prepare and practice their skits.  You can reconfigure groups so
label: BODY

text: that there are 4 small groups who will then perform their skit to the large group.  Have each
label: BODY

text: group perform their skit, and give 5 minutes after the skit for group feedback.
label: BODY

text: P O S T - T E S T ,  R E F L E C T I O N ,  A N D  P L A N  O F  A C T I O N
label: BODY

text: 7 5  M I N U T E S
label: BODY

text: GOAL: to review what participants have learned, what they liked best about the training, how
label: BODY

text: they will use their knowledge to reach other workers, and goals in their own jobs.
label: BODY

text: Have participants go around in a circle and share with the group, in one minute or less:
label: BODY

text: One thing they learned at the training;
label: BODY

text: One thing they will do differently in their job based on what they learned; and
label: BODY

text: One idea about how they can share what they have learned with other workers.
label: BODY

text: Distribute the Post-Test and ask participants to spend 10 minutes completing it.  Collect the
label: BODY

text: tests.
label: BODY

text: After collecting the tests, spend 5-10 minutes taking questions from participants.  Was there
label: BODY

text: anything they didn’t remember or had questions about, especially after taking the test?  Any
label: BODY

text: areas where they would like more information?
label: BODY

text: Next: distribute Handout #9, the Plan of Action.  Explain to participants that they should now
label: BODY

text: each spend 10 minutes on their own, thinking about what commitment they can make to
label: BODY

text: sharing the information they learned with their community.
label: BODY

text: Have participants break up in to their small groups and spend 15 minutes presenting their Plans
label: BODY

text: of Action to each other.  Come back as a large group, and ask participants to share any last
label: BODY

text: thoughts or ideas with the large group.
label: BODY

text: If you have prepared certificates ahead of time, distribute certificates to participants.  (If not,
label: BODY

text: tell participants you will mail them their certificate.)
label: BODY

text: End with a Unity Clap.  Have participants stand in a circle, and begin clapping in unison slowly.
label: BODY

text: Slowly increase the speed of clapping, and as the momentum builds, the group converges in the
label: BODY

text: middle with a shout of “Sí se puede!” or “Yes we can!”
label: BODY

text: E N D  O F  T R A I N I N G .

text: H A N D O U T  1 :  N E W  Y O R K  C I T Y  F A C T O R Y  F I R E
label: BODY

text: March 25, 4:40pm. A fire breaks out in a factory in a 10-story building.  There is no fire alarm in
label: BODY

text: the factory, which occupies the 8th, 9th, and 10th floors. Workers on the 8th floor phone upstairs
label: BODY

text: to workers on the 10th to warn them.  But there is no way to contact workers on the 9th floor.
label: BODY

text: Workers begin to panic, desperate to escape the spreading fire.  But there is only a small
label: BODY

text: elevator located in the back of the building and one stairway. Every day, the managers lock all
label: BODY

text: the other doors, exits, and the front elevator to prevent employee “theft.”
label: BODY

text: The building has only one fire escape, which is poorly built and in disrepair.  It quickly gives way,
label: BODY

text: causing workers to fall nearly 100 ft.
label: BODY

text: The fire department arrives on the scene, but their ladders only reach the 6th floor.  They
label: BODY

text: unwind their hoses, but water pressure is weak – and the stream of water only reaches the 7th
label: BODY

text: floor.  Their nets are weak, and fail to hold workers leaping from the burning building.
label: BODY

text: The building doors open inwards, rather than out, causing further chaos as panicked workers
label: BODY

text: try to flee.
label: BODY

text: By the end of the disaster, 146 of the approximately 500 workers in the factory died that day.
label: BODY

text: Sixty-two of those who died had jumped, fallen or were pushed from the top floors windows.
label: BODY

text: Tragically, there had already been four fires reported in this factory previously.  Investigations
label: BODY

text: later showed the fire started when a cigarette was thrown in a waste bin that had accumulated
label: BODY

text: over two months’ worth of trash.
label: BODY

text: Questions for Discussion:
label: BODY

text: 1. Where in New York City do you think this took place?  What borough or neighborhood?
label: BODY

text: 2. What kind of factory do you think it was?
label: BODY

text: 3. What year do you think it happened?
label: BODY

text: 4. How many days a week and hours a day do you think these workers worked?
label: BODY

text: 5. Who do you think these workers were?  Where were they from?  Were the men or
label: BODY

text: women?  How old do you think they were?
label: BODY

text: 6. What are some of the reasons this disaster happened?
label: BODY

text: H A N D O U T  # 1 :  I N C E N D I O  E N  U N A  F Á B R I C A  D E  N U E V A  Y O R K
label: BODY

text: 25 de marzo, 4:40pm. Comienza un incendio en una fábrica localizada en un edificio de 10
label: BODY

text: pisos. No hay alarma de incendios en la fábrica, que ocupa el octavo, noveno y décimo piso. Los
label: BODY

text: trabajadores en el octavo piso llaman por teléfono a los trabajadores del décimo piso para
label: BODY

text: advertirles. Sin embargo no hay forma de contactar a los trabajadores del noveno piso.
label: BODY

text: Los trabajadores entran en pánico, desesperados por escapar del incendio que se va
label: BODY

text: extendiendo por toda la fábrica. Pero sólo hay un ascensor pequeño localizado en la parte de
label: BODY

text: atrás del edificio y unas escaleras. Todos los días, los gerentes cerraban las demás puertas,
label: BODY

text: salidas y el otro ascensor en la parte frontal al edificio para prevenir que los empleados
label: BODY

text: “robaran” mercancía.
label: BODY

text: El edificio sólo tiene una escalera de incendios, que está mal construida y en mal estado.
label: BODY

text: Rápidamente se descompone, provocando que los trabajadores caigan desde una altura de casi
label: BODY

text: 100 pies.
label: BODY

text: El departamento de incendios llega al lugar, pero sus escaleras sólo llegan al sexto piso. Utilizan
label: BODY

text: sus mangueras, pero la presión de agua es débil, y la corriente de agua sólo llega el séptimo
label: BODY

text: piso. Las redes son débiles, y no logran para atrapar a las personas que van cayendo desde el
label: BODY

text: edificio en llamas.
label: BODY

text: Las puertas del edificio abren hacia adentro en vez de hacia afuera, causando aún más caos
label: BODY

text: mientras los trabajadores están desesperados por salir.
label: BODY

text: Al final de la catástrofe, 146 de los aproximadamente 500 trabajadores en la fábrica murieron
label: BODY

text: ese día. 62 de las víctimas saltaron, se cayeron o fueron empujados desde las ventanas del
label: BODY

text: edificio.
label: BODY

text: Trágicamente, ya habían ocurrido cuatro incendios en esta fábrica anteriormente. Al hacer una
label: BODY

text: investigación del incidente, se cree que el incendio comenzó al echar un cigarrillo en un cubo de
label: BODY

text: basura que tenía acumulada la basura de aproximadamente 2 meses.
label: BODY

text: Preguntas de discusión
label: BODY

text: 1. ¿En qué lugar de Nueva York crees que ocurrió este evento? ¿En qué barrio o
label: BODY

text: vecindario?
label: BODY

text: 2. ¿Qué tipo de fábrica crees que era?
label: BODY

text: 3. ¿En qué año crees que sucedió?
label: BODY

text: 4. ¿Cuántos días a la semana y horas al día crees que estos trabajadores trabajaban?
label: BODY

text: 5. ¿Quiénes crees que eran estos trabajadores? ¿De dónde eran? ¿Eran hombres o
label: BODY

text: mujeres? ¿Qué edades crees que tenían?
label: BODY

text: 6. ¿Cuáles son algunas de las razones por las cuales sucedió este desastre?
label: BODY

text: H A N D O U T  # 2 :  S T A T I S T I C S  O N  W O R K E R  H E A L T H  &  S A F E T Y 7
label: BODY

text: In 2009, an average of 12 workers were killed every day on the job in the U.S.
label: BODY

text: (Total 4,340 workers a year.)
label: BODY

text: That same year, another 50,000 were killed from occupational disease –
label: BODY

text: diseases caused by conditions at work.
label: BODY

text: Estimates suggest that about 8 million to 12 million job injuries or illnesses
label: BODY

text: occur every year.
label: BODY

text: Latino workers continued to have a greater risk of job fatalities.
label: BODY

text: There were 668 fatalities among Latino workers;
label: BODY

text: Of those, 59% (393) were born outside the U.S.
label: BODY

text: The Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire happened in 1911.  The first federal law
label: BODY

text: to protect workers’ health and safety on the job was not passed until 1970 –
label: BODY

text: nearly 60 years later.
label: BODY

text: 7 Statistics taken from the AFL-CIO Report Death on the Job: The Toll of Neglect, April 2011.  Available at
label: BODY

text: http://www.aflcio.org/issues/safety/memorial/doj_2011.cfm.
label: BODY

text: H A N D O U T  #  2 :  E S T A D Í S T I C A S  D E  S A L U D  Y  S E G U R I D A D  D E  L O S  T R A B A J A D O R E S 8
label: BODY

text: En el 2009, un promedio de 12 trabajadores perdieron la vida todos los días
label: BODY

text: en el trabajo en Estados Unidos (Un total de 4,430 trabajadores al año).
label: BODY

text: Ese mismo año, otros 50,000 murieron como causa de lesiones y
label: BODY

text: enfermedades ocupacionales causadas por condiciones en el trabajo.
label: BODY

text: Se estima que ocurren anualmente aproximadamente entre 8 y 12 millones
label: BODY

text: de lesiones o enfermedades ocupacionales.
label: BODY

text: Los trabajadores latinos continuaron teniendo el mayor riesgo de perder la
label: BODY

text: vida en el trabajo.
label: BODY

text: o Hubo 668 muertes entre trabajadores latinos.
label: BODY

text: o De ellos, el 59% (393) nacieron fuera de los Estados Unidos.
label: BODY

text: El incendio de la “Triangle Shirtwaist Factory” ocurrió en 1911. La primera ley
label: BODY

text: para proteger la salud y seguridad de los trabajadores no fue aprobada hasta
label: BODY

text: 1970 – casi 60 años más tarde.
label: BODY

text: 8 Información de AFL-CIO Report Death on the Job: The Toll of Neglect, April 2011 de
label: BODY

text: http://www.aflcio.org/issues/safety/memorial/doj_2011.cfm.

text: H A N D O U T  # 8 :  W O R K E R S ’  R I G H T S  U N D E R  O S H A
label: BODY

text: Workers, regardless of immigration status, have the following rights under OSHA:
label: BODY

text: 1) A healthy and safe workplace, free from known hazards that can cause death or serious
label: BODY

text: physical harm.
label: BODY

text: a. If an unsafe condition exists, your employer must try to control the hazard, for
label: BODY

text: example by substituting less hazardous materials or work practices.
label: BODY

text: b. If the hazard cannot be completely controlled, your employer must provide you
label: BODY

text: personal protective equipment (PPE) to protect you from the hazard.
label: BODY

text: 2) Information about:
label: BODY

text: a. Dangerous chemicals used in your job.
label: BODY

text: b. Information on injuries or illnesses that happen at your worksite.
label: BODY

text: i. If there are more than 10 workers on the job, the employer must keep an
label: BODY

text: OSHA 300 log of all injuries and illnesses.
label: BODY

text: c. Your rights as a worker.
label: BODY

text: 3) Training about how to perform your job safely, according to the OSHA rules that apply.
label: BODY

text: 4) Reporting unsafe working conditions.  You can:
label: BODY

text: a. Ask your employer to correct unsafe working conditions.  For imminent dangers,
label: BODY

text: workers should call OSHA immediately (1-800-321-OSHA).
label: BODY

text: b. File a complaint with OSHA anonymously about the condition.
label: BODY

text: c. Participate in OSHA investigations and get information about the resolution.
label: BODY

text: 5) Protection against retaliation:
label: BODY

text: a. Your employer can’t retaliate against you for reporting an unsafe condition or
label: BODY

text: participating in an OSHA investigation.  Report instances of retaliation to OSHA
label: BODY

text: immediately, but no later than 30 days after it happens!
label: BODY

text: b. Examples of what may count as retaliation include: firing or laying off,
label: BODY

text: blacklisting, demoting, denying overtime or promotions, discipline, intimidation,
label: BODY

text: threats, reduction of hours or pay, etc.
label: BODY

text: CONTACT OSHA by calling: (1-800-321-OSHA) or visiting the website at www.osha.gov.
label: BODY

text: H A N D O U T  # 8 :  D E R E C H O S  D E  L O S  T R A B A J A D O R E S  B A J O  O S H A
label: BODY

text: Los trabajadores, independientemente de su estatus migratorio, tienen los siguientes derechos
label: BODY

text: bajo OSHA:
label: BODY

text: 1. Un lugar de trabajo saludable, libre de riesgos reconocidos que puedan causar la
label: BODY

text: muerte o daños físicos graves.
label: BODY

text: a. Si existe una condición no segura, tu patrono tiene que intentar controlar el
label: BODY

text: riesgo, por ejemplo sustituyendo los materiales peligrosos por materiales menos
label: BODY

text: peligrosos o modificando las prácticas de trabajo.
label: BODY

text: b. Si el riesgo no se puede controlar completamente, tu patrono debe proveerte
label: BODY

text: equipo de protección personal (EPP) para protegerte del riesgo.
label: BODY

text: 2. Información acerca de:
label: BODY

text: a. Sustancias químicas peligrosas utilizadas en tu lugar de trabajo.
label: BODY

text: b. Información de lesiones o enfermedades que han sucedido en tu trabajo.
label: BODY

text: i. Si hay más de 10 trabajadores, el patrono debe tener un registro OSHA
label: BODY

text: 300 de todas las lesiones y enfermedades.
label: BODY

text: c. Tus derechos como trabajador.
label: BODY

text: 3. Entrenamiento acerca de cómo desempañarte en tu trabajo seguramente, de acuerdo a
label: BODY

text: las normas de OSHA que apliquen.
label: BODY

text: 4. Reportar condiciones de trabajo no seguras. Puedes:
label: BODY

text: a. Pedirle al patrono que corrija condiciones de trabajo no seguras. Para peligros
label: BODY

text: inminentes, los trabajadores deben contactar a OSHA inmediatamente (1-800-
label: BODY

text: 321-OSHA).
label: BODY

text: b. Presentar una queja a OSHA anónimamente acerca de la condición.
label: BODY

text: c. Participar en investigaciones de OSHA y obtener información acerca del
label: BODY

text: resultado.
label: BODY

text: 5. Protección en contra de represalias:
label: BODY

text: a. Tu patrono no puede tomar represalias en tu contra por reportar una condición
label: BODY

text: no segura o participar en una investigación de OSHA. Reporta casos de
label: BODY

text: represalias a OSHA inmediatamente, ¡pero no más tarde de 30 días después de
label: BODY

text: que suceda!
label: BODY

text: b. Ejemplos de lo que puede considerarse como represalias incluyen: despidos,
label: BODY

text: descensos en el puesto de trabajo, negar horas extra o ascensos, disciplina,
label: BODY

text: intimidación, amenazas, reducción en horas de trabajo o paga, etc.
label: BODY

text: Contacte a OSHA llamando al: (1-800-321-OSHA), o visitando su página web: www.osha.gov.
label: BODY
